cards.name: Abeyance
cards.text:
Until end of turn, target player can't cast instant or sorcery spells, and that player can't activate abilities that aren't mana abilities.
Draw a card.
cards.flavorText:
"I'm too modest a wizard to reveal the full extent of my abilities."
—Ertai, wizard adept

rulings.text: Abeyance prohibits activated abilities of cards which are not on the battlefield.
Abeyance never prevents mana abilities from being activated.
Abeyance does not affect abilities which are not activated, such as static abilities and triggered abilities. It also doesn’t stop the declaration of attackers or blockers.
This can’t be used as a counterspell. It will have no effect on spells which were on the stack when it was cast, nor on those cast in response to it.

cards.name: Cataclysm
cards.text: Each player chooses from among the permanents they control an artifact, a creature, an enchantment, and a land, then sacrifices the rest.
cards.flavorText: The *Weatherlight* dragged the *Predator* behind it, the cradle hauling the casket.

rulings.text: If you control a permanent with more than one type, you can choose that same permanent for more than one of the choices if you want to. This makes it possible to select an artifact creature as both your artifact and creature, and then select a land and thereby keep only two cards.

If you control a permanent with more than one type, you can choose that permanent to be the representative of either type. This makes it possible to have more than one creature (or other permanent type) on the battlefield. For example, if you select a creature for your creature and an artifact creature for your artifact, you get to keep both of these creatures.
The permanents to save are chosen on resolution. You do not choose them when casting the spell.
The current player makes their choices before the other player. After both players make choices, all the sacrifices are done simultaneously.
Each permanent not chosen by a player will be sacrificed. If a permanent has none of the listed types (for example, a Planeswalker with no other types), it can’t be chosen.

cards.name: Armageddon
cards.text: Destroy all lands.

cards.name: Aura of Silence
cards.text:
Artifact and enchantment spells your opponents cast cost {2} more to cast.
Sacrifice Aura of Silence: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

rulings.text: Aura of Silence affects all opponents in a multiplayer game.

cards.name: Aura of Silence
cards.text:
Artifact and enchantment spells your opponents cast cost {2} more to cast.
Sacrifice Aura of Silence: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

rulings.text: Aura of Silence affects all opponents in a multiplayer game.

cards.name: Nomads en-Kor
cards.text: {0}: The next 1 damage that would be dealt to Nomads en-Kor this turn is dealt to target creature you control instead.
cards.flavorText: The Kor forsake roots for the winding of the path; forsake voices for the silence of the mind; forsake all else for the poverty of isolation.

rulings.text: The ability of this card does not do anything to stop Trample damage from being assigned to the defending player.
It can redirect damage to itself.
It is possible to redirect more damage to a creature than that creature’s toughness.
You can use this ability as much as you want prior to damage being dealt.
When you redirect combat damage it is still combat damage.

cards.name: Paladin en-Vec
cards.text: First strike, protection from black and from red (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike. It can't be blocked, targeted, dealt damage, or enchanted by anything black or red.)
cards.flavorText: "Our belief shall be the lance that pierces Volrath's heart."

cards.name: Empyrial Armor
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +1/+1 for each card in your hand.
cards.flavorText:
"An angel appeared in the smoldering skies above the fray, her clothes as flames, her armor as fire."
—"Hymn of Angelfire"

rulings.text: The value of X is recalculated constantly, so this card’s bonus varies as the number of cards in your hand varies.

cards.name: Cloudchaser Eagle
cards.text:
Flying
When Cloudchaser Eagle enters the battlefield, destroy target enchantment.
cards.flavorText:
When the eagle catches a cloud, it tears it into strips that fall to earth.
—Vec myth of the rains

rulings.text: It destroys one of your enchantments if you are the only player with any enchantments.
Nothing happens if there are no legal enchantments to target when it enters the battlefield.

cards.name: Disenchant
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavorText: The swarm seemed unmoved by the artificial slivers' destruction. "They clearly were not the leaders," Hanna cursed. "I guess we'll have to do this the hard way."

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.name: Disenchant
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavorText: The swarm seemed unmoved by the artificial slivers' destruction. "They clearly were not the leaders," Hanna cursed. "I guess we'll have to do this the hard way."

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.name: Soltari Visionary
cards.text:
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
Whenever Soltari Visionary deals damage to a player, destroy target enchantment that player controls.

rulings.text: If the damaged player controls any enchantments, you must choose one to be destroyed. If they do not, nothing happens.

cards.name: Soul Warden
cards.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavorText:
Count carefully the souls and see that none are lost.
—Vec teaching

rulings.text: Does not trigger on a card on the battlefield being changed into a creature.
The ability will not trigger on itself entering the battlefield, but it will trigger on any other creature that is put onto the battlefield at the same time.
Two Soul Wardens entering the battlefield at the same time will each cause the other’s ability to trigger.
The life gain is mandatory.

cards.name: Tithe
cards.text: Search your library for a Plains card. If target opponent controls more lands than you, you may search your library for an additional Plains card. Reveal those cards, put them into your hand, then shuffle.

rulings.text: Counts lands on resolution, not on announcement.
Because the “search” requires you to find a card with certain characteristics, you don’t have to find the card if you don’t want to.

cards.name: Warrior en-Kor
cards.text: {0}: The next 1 damage that would be dealt to Warrior en-Kor this turn is dealt to target creature you control instead.
cards.flavorText: Only a matter as vital as destroying Volrath could bring together the reclusive Kor people.

rulings.text: It is possible to redirect more damage to a creature than that creature’s toughness.
You can use this ability as much as you want prior to damage being dealt.
The ability of this card does not do anything to stop Trample damage from being assigned to the defending player.
It can redirect damage to itself.
When you redirect combat damage it is still combat damage.

cards.name: Memory Lapse
cards.text: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on top of its owner's library instead of into that player's graveyard.
cards.flavorText:
"Um . . . oh . . . what was I saying?"
—Reveka, Wizard Savant

rulings.text: Memory Lapse has a self-replacement effect that replaces the spell going to the graveyard before any other effect can replace that event. If the spell was cast using flashback, however, flashback will change the spell’s destination from its owner’s library to exile.

cards.name: Impulse
cards.text: Look at the top four cards of your library. Put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.
cards.flavorText:
"Controlling time ensures you need never look impulsive again."
—Teferi

rulings.text: This is not a draw.
Due to errata, you no longer shuffle your library.

cards.name: Forbid
cards.text:
Buyback—Discard two cards. (You may discard two cards in addition to any other costs as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Counter target spell.

cards.name: Mana Leak
cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {3}.
cards.flavorText:
"The fatal flaw in every plan is the assumption that you know more than your enemy."
—Volrath

cards.name: Man-o'-War
cards.text: When Man-o'-War enters the battlefield, return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.flavorText:
"Beauty to the eye does not always translate to the touch."
—Naimah, Femeref philosopher

rulings.text: If there are no other creatures on the battlefield when Man-o’-War enters the battlefield, its ability must target itself.

cards.name: Sea Sprite
cards.text: Flying, protection from red
cards.flavorText:
"No one can catch what won't be caught."
—Kakra, Sea Troll

cards.name: Rainbow Efreet
cards.text:
Flying
{U}{U}: Rainbow Efreet phases out. (While it's phased out, it's treated as though it doesn't exist. It phases in before you untap during your next untap step.)
cards.flavorText:
"A beauty made more so by its fleeting visitations."
—Teferi

cards.name: Soltari Monk
cards.text:
Protection from black
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
cards.flavorText:
"Prayer rarely explains."
—Orim, Samite healer

cards.name: Soltari Priest
cards.text:
Protection from red
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
cards.flavorText: "In Rath," the priest said, "there is even greater need for prayer."

rulings.text: Once a creature has been blocked, that creature remains blocked and will deal and be dealt combat damage even if it gains or loses shadow or if the blocking creature gains or loses shadow.
If an attacking creature has multiple evasion abilities, such as shadow and flying, a creature can block it only if that creature satisfies all of the appropriate evasion abilities.
Multiple instances of shadow on the same creature are redundant.

cards.name: Staunch Defenders
cards.text: When Staunch Defenders enters the battlefield, you gain 4 life.
cards.flavorText:
"Hold your position! Leave doubt for the dying!"
—Tahngarth of the *Weatherlight*

cards.name: Capsize
cards.text:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Return target permanent to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Counterspell
cards.text: Counter target spell.
cards.flavorText:
"It was probably a lousy spell in the first place."
—Ertai, wizard adept

cards.name: Dismiss
cards.text:
Counter target spell.
Draw a card.
cards.flavorText:
"There is nothing you can do that I cannot simply deny."
—Ertai, wizard adept

cards.name: Force Spike
cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {1}.

rulings.text: The payment is optional.

cards.name: Dissipate
cards.text: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, exile it instead of putting it into its owner's graveyard.
cards.flavorText:
"If you weren't born with it, you don't need it."
—Grahilah, former trader of Amiqat

rulings.text: The card does not go to the graveyard before being exiled.
If the spell is not countered (because the spell it targets can't be countered), then it does not get exiled.

cards.name: Spirit Link
cards.text:
Enchant creature (Target a creature as you cast this. This card enters the battlefield attached to that creature.)
Whenever enchanted creature deals damage, you gain that much life.
cards.flavorText:
"I regret feeding Kaervek's hunger for power—far better to live with animals innocent of such ambitions."
—Jolrael

rulings.text: You only gain the life when the triggered ability resolves. If you are reduced to zero life before the ability resolves, you will lose before gaining the life.

You gain life for all damage which is not prevented, regardless of what the creature damages (player or another creature) or the toughness of the blocking creature. If you put this on a 5/5 and it is blocked by a 1/1, you still gain 5 life.

cards.name: Nekrataal
cards.text:
First strike
When Nekrataal enters the battlefield, destroy target nonartifact, nonblack creature. That creature can't be regenerated.
cards.flavorText:
"I have seen the horrors Kaervek has freed. My betrayal is certain—but of Kaervek or of Jamuraa, I cannot say."
—Jolrael

rulings.text: Nothing happens if there are no nonartifact, nonblack creatures on the battlefield when Nekrataal enters the battlefield, but if there is one, you must target it, even if it’s a creature you control.

cards.name: White Knight
cards.text:
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
Protection from black (This creature can't be blocked, targeted, dealt damage, or enchanted by anything black.)
cards.flavorText: Out of the blackness and stench of the engulfing swamp emerged a shimmering figure. Only the splattered armor and ichor-stained sword hinted at the unfathomable evil the knight had just laid waste.

cards.name: Hydroblast
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Counter target spell if it's red.
• Destroy target permanent if it's red.
cards.flavorText:
"Heed the lessons of our time: the forms of water may move the land itself and hold captive the fires within."
—Gustha Ebbasdotter, Kjeldoran Royal Mage

rulings.text: The decision to counter a spell or destroy a permanent is a decision made on announcement before the target is selected. If the spell is redirected, this mode can’t be changed, so only targets of the selected type are valid.
Hydroblast can target any spell or permanent, not just a red one. It checks the color of the target only on resolution.

cards.name: Recurring Nightmare
cards.text: Sacrifice a creature, Return Recurring Nightmare to its owner's hand: Return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield. Activate only as a sorcery.
cards.flavorText:
"I am confined by sleep and defined by nightmare."
—Crovax

rulings.text: If you cast this as normal during your main phase, it will enter the battlefield and you’ll receive priority. If no abilities trigger because of this, you can activate its ability immediately, before any other player has a chance to remove it from the battlefield.

cards.name: Thrull Surgeon
cards.text: {1}{B}, Sacrifice Thrull Surgeon: Look at target player's hand and choose a card from it. That player discards that card. Activate only as a sorcery.
cards.flavorText: "Just take a little off the top."

cards.name: Fireblast
cards.text:
You may sacrifice two Mountains rather than pay this spell's mana cost.
Fireblast deals 4 damage to any target.
cards.flavorText: Embermages aren't well known for their diplomatic skills.

cards.name: Mogg Flunkies
cards.text: Mogg Flunkies can't attack or block alone.
cards.flavorText: They'll attack whatever's in front of them—as long as you tell them where that is.

rulings.text: If you control more than one Mogg Flunkies, they can attack or block together, even if no other creatures attack or block.

Although Mogg Flunkies can’t attack alone, other attacking creatures don’t have to attack the same player or planeswalker. For example, Mogg Flunkies could attack an opponent and another creature could attack a planeswalker that opponent controls. Similarly, other blocking creatures don’t have to block the same creature that Mogg Flunkies blocks.
Once Mogg Flunkies has attacked or blocked, it will remain in combat even if you no longer control another attacking or blocking creature.
If an effect says that Mogg Flunkies attacks or blocks if able and you control another creature able to attack or block, you must attack or block with Mogg Flunkies and that creature.
In a Two-Headed Giant game, Mogg Flunkies can attack or block with a creature controlled by your teammate, even if no other creatures you control are attacking or blocking.

cards.name: Dwarven Thaumaturgist
cards.text: {T}: Switch target creature's power and toughness until end of turn.

rulings.text: Note that the wording “Effects that alter the creature’s power alter its toughness instead, and vice versa, this turn” has been removed.
Effects that switch power and toughness apply after all other effects that change power and/or toughness, regardless of which effect was created first.
Switching a creature’s power and toughness twice (or any even number of times) effectively returns the creature to the power and toughness it had before any switches.

cards.name: Shock
cards.text: Shock deals 2 damage to any target.
cards.flavorText:
Lightning tethers souls to the world.
—Kor saying

cards.name: Tradewind Rider
cards.text:
Flying
{T}, Tap two untapped creatures you control: Return target permanent to its owner's hand.
cards.flavorText: It is said that the wind will blow the world past if you wait long enough.

cards.name: Viashino Sandstalker
cards.text:
Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)
At the beginning of the end step, return Viashino Sandstalker to its owner's hand. (Return it only if it's on the battlefield.)
cards.flavorText:
"Some believe Sandstalkers to be illusions; those with scars know better."
—*Zhalfirin Guide to the Desert*

rulings.text: It is returned to its owner’s hand at the end of any turn in which it is on the battlefield.

cards.name: Firestorm
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, discard X cards.
Firestorm deals X damage to each of X targets.
cards.flavorText:
"Glok loved storms! He'd sit an' watch an' laugh through the whole thing. I miss him."
—Squee, goblin cabin hand

rulings.text: For example, if you discard four cards, you must target four different creatures and/or players. Firestorm will deal 4 damage to each of them.
The value of X can’t exceed the number of cards in your hand or the number of available legal targets, whichever is smaller. X can be 0.
The same permanent or player can’t be targeted more than once.

cards.name: Firestorm
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, discard X cards.
Firestorm deals X damage to each of X targets.
cards.flavorText:
"Glok loved storms! He'd sit an' watch an' laugh through the whole thing. I miss him."
—Squee, goblin cabin hand

rulings.text: For example, if you discard four cards, you must target four different creatures and/or players. Firestorm will deal 4 damage to each of them.
The value of X can’t exceed the number of cards in your hand or the number of available legal targets, whichever is smaller. X can be 0.
The same permanent or player can’t be targeted more than once.

cards.name: Shattering Pulse
cards.text:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Destroy target artifact.

cards.name: Whispers of the Muse
cards.text:
Buyback {5} (You may pay an additional {5} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Draw a card.
cards.flavorText:
"I followed her song only to find it was a dirge."
—Crovax

cards.name: Goblin Vandal
cards.text: Whenever Goblin Vandal attacks and isn't blocked, you may pay {R}. If you do, destroy target artifact defending player controls and Goblin Vandal assigns no combat damage this turn.

rulings.text: If the defending player controls no artifacts that you can target, the ability doesn’t go on the stack and you can’t pay {R}.

An ability that triggers when something “attacks and isn’t blocked” triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.name: Emerald Charm
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Untap target permanent.
• Destroy target non-Aura enchantment.
• Target creature loses flying until end of turn.

cards.name: City of Brass
cards.text:
Whenever City of Brass becomes tapped, it deals 1 damage to you.
{T}: Add one mana of any color.

rulings.text: The first ability triggers no matter how the land becomes tapped.

If you tap City of Brass while you are casting a spell or activating an ability, its ability will trigger and wait. When you finish casting that spell or activating that ability, City of Brass’s triggered ability is put on the stack on top of it. City of Brass’s ability will resolve first.

On the other hand, you can tap City of Brass, put its triggered ability on the stack, and then respond to that ability by casting an instant or activating an ability using that mana. In that case, the instant spell or activated ability will resolve first.

cards.name: Orcish Settlers
cards.text: {X}{X}{R}, {T}, Sacrifice Orcish Settlers: Destroy X target lands.
cards.flavorText: They wouldn't know their house from a charred hole in the ground.

cards.name: Spike Feeder
cards.text:
Spike Feeder enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: You gain 2 life.

cards.name: Uktabi Orangutan
cards.text: When Uktabi Orangutan enters the battlefield, destroy target artifact.
cards.flavorText:
"Is it true that the apes wear furs of gold when they marry?"
—Rana, Suq'Ata market fool

cards.name: Wall of Blossoms
cards.text:
Defender
When Wall of Blossoms enters the battlefield, draw a card.
cards.flavorText: Each flower identical, every leaf and petal disturbingly exact.

cards.name: Spike Weaver
cards.text:
Spike Weaver enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Weaver: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
{1}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Weaver: Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn.

rulings.text: The second ability includes your own creatures as well.

cards.name: Survival of the Fittest
cards.text: {G}, Discard a creature card: Search your library for a creature card, reveal that card, put it into your hand, then shuffle.

rulings.text: Because the “search” requires you to find a card with certain characteristics, you don’t have to find the card if you don’t want to.

cards.name: Dread of Night
cards.text: White creatures get -1/-1.
cards.flavorText:
"These moonless, foreign skies keep me in thrall. Dark whispers echo in the night, and I cannot resist."
—Selenia, dark angel

cards.name: Volrath's Stronghold
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}{B}, {T}: Put target creature card from your graveyard on top of your library.
cards.flavorText: The seed of a world's evil.

cards.name: Spirit of the Night
cards.text:
Flying, trample, haste, protection from black
Spirit of the Night has first strike as long as it's attacking.

cards.name: Phyrexian Furnace
cards.text:
{T}: Exile the bottom card of target player's graveyard.
{1}, Sacrifice Phyrexian Furnace: Exile target card from a graveyard. Draw a card.

cards.name: Gemstone Mine
cards.text:
Gemstone Mine enters the battlefield with three mining counters on it.
{T}, Remove a mining counter from Gemstone Mine: Add one mana of any color. If there are no mining counters on Gemstone Mine, sacrifice it.

rulings.text: Sacrificing this card when the last counter is removed is part of the effect of tapping it for mana.

If the last mining counter is removed from Gemstone Mine in some way other than activating its ability (such as Chisei, Heart of Oceans), Gemstone Mine won’t be sacrificed but its ability can’t be activated.

cards.name: Boil
cards.text: Destroy all Islands.
cards.flavorText:
"The fishers will throw out their nets and draw them back filled with dust."
—Oracle *en*-Vec

cards.name: Quicksand
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{T}, Sacrifice Quicksand: Target attacking creature without flying gets -1/-2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Undiscovered Paradise
cards.text: {T}: Add one mana of any color. During your next untap step, as you untap your permanents, return Undiscovered Paradise to its owner's hand.
cards.flavorText: Jolrael's choice of homes was far better than her choice of allies.

rulings.text: It will return even if some effect prevents you from untapping it. The ability is not replacing the untapping of the land in any way.
Only returns to owner’s hand if it is still on the battlefield at the beginning of its controller’s next untap.

cards.name: Dwarven Miner
cards.text: {2}{R}, {T}: Destroy target nonbasic land.
cards.flavorText:
"Fetch the pestridder, Paka—we've got dwarves in the rutabagas!"
—Jamul, Femeref farmer

cards.name: Final Fortune
cards.text: Take an extra turn after this one. At the beginning of that turn's end step, you lose the game.
cards.flavorText:
Want all, lose all.
—Zhalfirin aphorism

rulings.text: If you end up skipping the extra turn that is gained, you do not lose the game.
If multiple “extra turn” effects resolve in the same turn, take them in the reverse of the order that the effects resolved.

cards.name: Hammer of Bogardan
cards.text:
Hammer of Bogardan deals 3 damage to any target.
{2}{R}{R}{R}: Return Hammer of Bogardan from your graveyard to your hand. Activate only during your upkeep.

cards.name: Jackal Pup
cards.text: Whenever Jackal Pup is dealt damage, it deals that much damage to you.
cards.flavorText: The first morning after acquiring her familiar, the wizard awoke with fleabites and mange.

cards.name: Incinerate
cards.text: Incinerate deals 3 damage to any target. A creature dealt damage this way can't be regenerated this turn.
cards.flavorText:
"Never taunt an embermage, 'What are you going to do about it?'"
—Akin, seasoned askari

rulings.text: Regeneration abilities that would affect that creature can still be activated; they just won’t do anything. The creature can’t be regenerated for any reason, even if an effect other than Incinerate would deal lethal damage to it or otherwise destroy it.

cards.name: Mogg Fanatic
cards.text: Sacrifice Mogg Fanatic: It deals 1 damage to any target.
cards.flavorText: "I got it! I got it! I—"

rulings.text: Once Mogg Fanatic has dealt and been dealt combat damage, it’s too late to activate its ability before it’s destroyed.

cards.name: Ball Lightning
cards.text:
Trample (This creature can deal excess combat damage to the player or planeswalker it's attacking.)
Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)
At the beginning of the end step, sacrifice Ball Lightning.

rulings.text: The creature is sacrificed at the end of every turn in which it is on the battlefield. There is no choice about what turn to sacrifice it.

cards.name: Pyroblast
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Counter target spell if it's blue.
• Destroy target permanent if it's blue.
cards.flavorText:
"Just the thing for those pesky water mages."
—Jaya Ballard, Task Mage

rulings.text: The decision to counter a spell or destroy a permanent is a decision made on announcement before the target is selected. If the spell is redirected, this mode can’t be changed, so only targets of the selected type are valid.
Pyroblast can target any spell or permanent, not just a blue one. It checks the color of the target only on resolution.

cards.name: Pyroblast
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Counter target spell if it's blue.
• Destroy target permanent if it's blue.
cards.flavorText:
"Just the thing for those pesky water mages."
—Jaya Ballard, Task Mage

rulings.text: The decision to counter a spell or destroy a permanent is a decision made on announcement before the target is selected. If the spell is redirected, this mode can’t be changed, so only targets of the selected type are valid.
Pyroblast can target any spell or permanent, not just a blue one. It checks the color of the target only on resolution.

cards.name: Hall of Gemstone
cards.text: At the beginning of each player's upkeep, that player chooses a color. Until end of turn, lands tapped for mana produce mana of the chosen color instead of any other color.

rulings.text: Although the color may be altered, any restrictions on the use of the mana are not removed.
Will not affect lands that do not produce mana.

This has the supertype world. When a world permanent enters the battlefield, any world permanents that were already on the battlefield are put into their owners’ graveyards. This is a state-based action called the “world rule.” The new world permanent stays on the battlefield. If two world permanents enter the battlefield at the same time, they’re both put into their owners’ graveyards.
Colorless mana added to a player’s mana pool isn’t affected.

cards.name: Ironclaw Orcs
cards.text: Ironclaw Orcs can't block creatures with power 2 or greater.
cards.flavorText: Generations of genetic weeding have given rise to the deviously cowardly Ironclaw clan.

cards.name: Wall of Roots
cards.text:
Defender
Put a -0/-1 counter on Wall of Roots: Add {G}. Activate only once each turn.
cards.flavorText: Sometimes the wise ones wove their magic into living plants; as the plant grew, so grew the magic.

rulings.text: If you must sacrifice a creature to pay a casting or activation cost that also includes mana, such as that of Bubbling Cauldron's abilities, you may put a -0/-1 counter on Wall of Roots to make its toughness 0 and then sacrifice it to pay that cost.

cards.name: Verdant Force
cards.text: At the beginning of each upkeep, create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.
cards.flavorText:
Burl, scurf, and bower
Birth fern and flower.

rulings.text: In Two-Headed Giant, triggers only once per upkeep, not once for each player.
Verdant Force’s ability triggers at the beginning of each upkeep, not just each of your upkeeps.

cards.name: Lobotomy
cards.text: Target player reveals their hand, then you choose a card other than a basic land card from it. Search that player's graveyard, hand, and library for all cards with the same name as the chosen card and exile them. Then that player shuffles.

rulings.text: If the player has no cards in their hand, you still get to look through their deck, but you do not get to exile any cards.
You only get to pick one card from the player’s hand.
It exiles the chosen card plus all others in the hand, library, and graveyard. Some people thought the chosen card was not exiled due to some vague wording.
Does not affect cards on the battlefield.
The copies must be found if they are in publicly viewable zones. Finding copies while searching private zones is optional.

cards.name: Bottle Gnomes
cards.text: Sacrifice Bottle Gnomes: You gain 3 life.
cards.flavorText:
"I am reminded of the fable of the silver egg. Its owner cracks it open to see what jewels it holds, only to discover a simple yellow yolk."
—Karn, silver golem

cards.name: Birds of Paradise
cards.text:
Flying
{T}: Add one mana of any color.

cards.name: Cursed Scroll
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Choose a card name, then reveal a card at random from your hand. If that card has the chosen name, Cursed Scroll deals 2 damage to any target.

rulings.text: If you have no cards in hand, you still have to name a card. Then you fail to reveal one (since there aren’t any). Since the named card wasn’t revealed, no damage is dealt.

cards.name: Cursed Scroll
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Choose a card name, then reveal a card at random from your hand. If that card has the chosen name, Cursed Scroll deals 2 damage to any target.

rulings.text: If you have no cards in hand, you still have to name a card. Then you fail to reveal one (since there aren’t any). Since the named card wasn’t revealed, no damage is dealt.

cards.name: Grindstone
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Target player mills two cards. If two cards that share a color were milled this way, repeat this process.
cards.flavorText:
"Memory is a burden that wears at the soul as weather wears at stone."
—Crovax

rulings.text: If the two cards are both colorless, then the effect does not repeat. It only repeats if both cards have at least one color and at least one color is shared between them.
The effect repeats as many times as it takes to meet the end condition.

cards.name: Scroll Rack
cards.text: {1}, {T}: Exile any number of cards from your hand face down. Put that many cards from the top of your library into your hand. Then look at the exiled cards and put them on top of your library in any order.

rulings.text: If there are not enough cards in the library, you do not lose. This is not a draw effect. You just get as many cards as are there, even if there are zero cards in the library.

cards.name: Reflecting Pool
cards.text: {T}: Add one mana of any type that a land you control could produce.
cards.flavorText:
"The reflection of land interests me far more than its reality."
—Volrath

rulings.text: Any replacement effects are considered by Reflecting Pool when determining the types of mana a land can produce.
Any change to a land’s type or splicing of text into a land can affect the types of mana a land can produce.
The types of mana are white, blue, black, red, green, and colorless.

Reflecting Pool checks the effects of all mana-producing abilities of lands you control, but it doesn’t check their costs. For example, Vivid Crag says “{T}, Remove a charge counter from Vivid Crag: Add one mana of any color.” If you control Vivid Crag and Reflecting Pool, you can tap Reflecting Pool for any color of mana. It doesn’t matter whether Vivid Crag has a charge counter on it, and it doesn’t matter whether it’s untapped.
Reflecting Pool doesn’t care about any restrictions or riders your lands put on the mana they produce, such as Pillar of the Paruns and Hall of the Bandit Lord do. It just cares about types of mana.

Multiple Reflecting Pools won’t help each other produce mana. If you control a Reflecting Pool, and all other lands you control either lack mana abilities or are other Reflecting Pools, you may still activate Reflecting Pool’s ability — it just won’t produce any mana.

cards.name: Stalking Stones
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{6}: Stalking Stones becomes a 3/3 Elemental artifact creature that's still a land. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn’t matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it’s already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

cards.text:

{T}, Sacrifice Wasteland: Destroy target nonbasic land.
cards.flavorText:
"The land promises nothing and keeps its promise."
—Oracle *en*-Vec

—Oracle *en*-Vec

cards.name: Nevinyrral's Disk
cards.text:
Nevinyrral's Disk enters the battlefield tapped.
{1}, {T}: Destroy all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments.

rulings.text: You don't sacrifice Nevinyrral's Disk to activate its ability. It's destroyed as part of the ability's resolution if it's still on the battlefield. If an effect gives Nevinyrral's Disk indestructible or regenerates it, it stays on the battlefield.

tokens.name: Randy Buehler Bio
tokens.text: Although twenty-six-year-old professional Magic® player Randy Buehler of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, didn't make the Top 8, he did finish with an impressive 6—1 record during the Standard portion of the World Championships. Buehler's Draw, Go deck is built for pure control with over twenty counters. He uses eight card-drawing spells to get to his counters more quickly and only four Stalking Stones and one Rainbow Efreet for offensive power. Buehler said he won some games without ever having to tap a land for mana on his own turn.

tokens.name: Ben Rubin Bio
tokens.text: Though only fifteen years old, Ben Rubin has amassed quite an impressive tournament record. He placed second at Pro Tour™—Los Angeles and finished in the Top 16 at Grand Prix—San Francisco, his hometown. Ben played the archetypal mono-red weenie or Sligh deck at the 1998 Worlds. Although he prefers to play a more balanced deck, Rubin thought the aggressive Sligh would work well at this tournament. His deck consists of roughly one-third land, one-third direct damage, and one-third small aggressive creatures.

tokens.name: Brian Selden Bio
tokens.text: Brian Selden, a seventeen-year-old high school student from San Diego, California, says his deck revolves around the interaction between Survival of the Fittest and Recurring Nightmare. The former is used to put creatures into the graveyard and the latter can then bring them into play. With this combo, Selden is able to use his creatures to react to an opponent's threats. The deck also contains over twenty creatures, many of which have an effect when they enter play or perform some other useful function, such as the Spike Weaver. Unlike many similar decks, Selden's dips into blue, primarily for Lobotomy. He said this was the key to many of his victories.

tokens.name: Brian Hacker Bio
tokens.text: Twenty-three-year-old professional Magic® player Brian Hacker of San Diego, California, thought he had a good chance of winning the finals with his white weenie deck. Hacker said his deck was well set up to defeat his opponents with its twenty-something aggressive creatures—including a number of shadow and en-Kor creatures. Unlike traditional white weenie decks, which rely on Armageddon as a major threat card, Hacker's deck uses Cataclysm, which he feels better complements the use of Empyrial Armor.
